acf.heading: Get a clindamycin prescription online.
acf.first_paragraph: Bacterial infections requiring antibiotic therapy are fairly common but should be dealt with quickly to avoid the spread and worsening of the infection.

accordion.accordion_title: What is clindamycin and how does it work?
accordion.accordion_intro: Clindamycin is an antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections in the body. It does so by stopping the growth of the bacteria. Clindamycin is a frequent antibiotic choice for patients who are allergic to penicillins.
accordion.accordion_content: If you think you need clindamycin, you can speak to a doctor on Maple to see if it is right for you.

accordion.accordion_title: What are the uses for clindamycin?
accordion.accordion_intro: Clindamycin is used to treat bacterial infections. This can include, but not limited to; strep throat, skin infections, ear infections, endocarditis, pneumonia, or joint infections.
accordion.accordion_content: You can find out if you have strep throat symptoms by speaking to a doctor on Maple here.

accordion.accordion_intro: Clindamycin should be taken as per the doctor’s recommendation. Typically, it is taken 4 times a day and is taken orally, with or without food. Doses of clindamycin vary based on a doctor’s recommendation but can vary from 600 mg a day up to 4,800 mg a day.
accordion.accordion_content: It’s important to speak to your doctor to find out the right dosage and frequency of the medication for you.

accordion.accordion_title: What are the side effects and risks of clindamycin?
accordion.accordion_intro: Clindamycin may cause nausea, vomiting or diarrhea. Additionally, some users may have hypersensitive reactions which could include oral thrush or vaginal yeast infection.
accordion.accordion_content: Tell your doctor right away if you have any worsening side effects or symptoms.

accordion.accordion_intro:
Clindamycin may contain active ingredients to which you may be allergic to.

If you have any questions about the medication, you can speak to a doctor on Maple by registering for an account.

Clindamycin does expire. Like most antibiotics, it has a shelf life of one year from the time of dispensing. It’s not dangerous to take clindamycin after expiry, though it may not be as effective. Expired clindamycin is recommended to be given to a medication take-back program for proper disposal. If you believe you need antibiotics, talk to a doctor on Maple to get an assessment. Note: it’s very important that you take your full course of antibiotics as instructed. Don’t save the remainder of your prescription for your next illness if you begin to feel better part way through your course of medication.
